bestBHT.bht: The workers, who endured the burden and scorching heat during a dry, east wind, express their dissatisfaction as others are made equal to them. While their complaint seems justified, it is important to remember that salvation is not earned through works alone. God does not differentiate between those who have labored longer or faced greater trials. All who are faithful in Christ, regardless of their journey, will partake in the same glory and happiness.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: These last have wrought but one hour, and thou hast made them equal unto us."
which have borne the burden and heat of the day."
Who have wrought not only longer but during a more trying period of the day.
Albert Barnes: The burden means the heavy labor, the severe toil.
We have continued at that toil in the heat of the day.
The others had worked only a little while, and that in the cool of the evening.
Marvin Vincent: Heat [καυσωνα] . Rev., the scorching heat. The word is from kaiw, to burn. It refers to the dry, scorching heat born by the east wind.
During harvest the corn cannot be winnowed if the east wind blows, for it would carry away both chaff and corn.

In Pharaoh 's dream (Genesis 41:6) the ears are blasted by it : Jonah's gourd is withered by it (Jonah 4:8), and the vine in Ezekiel's parable of the Babylonian captivity is blighted by it (Ezekiel 17:10).
Philip Schaff: Matthew 20:12. These last spent one hour, etc. A well-grounded complaint, if salvation were of works.
Archibald T. Robertson: Equal unto us. It was a regular protest against the supposed injustice of the householder.
A whole day's work on the part of these sweat-stained men who had stood also the sirocco, the hot, dry, dust-laden east wind.
They seemed to have a good case.
John Gill: This is grudged by the Jews... There is that obtains his world (or the world to come for himself) בשעה אחת, 'in one hour'; and there is that obtains it in many years.

The ceremonial law was a burden to the Jewish people... The law was a fiery law, and the dispensation of it was a hot and scorching one; it was uncomfortable working under the flashes of a mount, that burned with fire.

It rather seems that others will be made equal with them, who have not endured what they have done; for all the dead in Christ... will share in that glory; even the innumerable company, chosen, redeemed, and called, out of every nation, tongue, and people.
John Wesley: God hath put no difference between us (Jews) and them (Gentiles), purifying their hearts by faith.
Those who were equally holy here, whenever they were called, will be equally happy hereafter.

bhtAttempts.bht: These workers who have borne the burden and heat of the day, during a scorching east wind, express their discontent, believing it to be unjust that those who have worked shorter and easier hours be made equal to them. Their complaint seems well-founded, as they have endured a whole day's work under the intense heat and toiled heavily. However, this grudging attitude towards those who obtain salvation or glory in a short amount of time is a flawed perspective. In God's eyes, there is no difference or distinction between those who have labored long and endured hardships and those who have entered the fold later or with less tribulation.

These workers, who have endured the burden and scorching heat throughout the entire day, feel discontented that those who have only worked for a short while are being treated as equals. While their frustration seems valid considering the intensity of their labor, the idea that salvation should be solely based on works is flawed. Whether one has labored longer or come to faith later, God does not differentiate. All those who are faithful in Christ will share in the same ultimate happiness.

These workers, who have endured the burden and heat of the day during a scorching east wind, express their discontent in regards to those who have worked shorter hours. While their complaint seems well-founded, it is important to remember that salvation is not based solely on works. In God's eyes, there is no distinction between those who have toiled long and those who have not. All who are in Christ will share in the same glory and happiness.

These workers, who have borne the burden and heat of the day during a scorching east wind, complain about others being made equal to them. They feel justified in their frustration, having toiled all day under intense heat. However, it is crucial to realize that salvation is not solely reliant on works. In God's eyes, there is no distinction between those who have labored longer and those who have not. All who are faithful in Christ will ultimately share in the same joy and happiness.

The workers, who endured the burden and scorching heat during a dry, east wind, express their dissatisfaction as others are made equal to them. While their complaint seems justified, it is important to remember that salvation is not earned through works alone. God does not differentiate between those who have labored longer or faced greater trials. All who are faithful in Christ, regardless of their journey, will partake in the same glory and happiness.
